In complete forms (called classic forms: no enzyme activity): the clinical diagnosis in little girls is an abnormality of the external genitalia (from clitoral hypertrophy to a male appearance without testicles). The boy's genitals are normal.

In boys and girls, hypoglycaemia can cause hypotonia or even convulsions, persistent cholestatic jaundice and arterial hypotension. Mineralocorticoid deficiency leads to poor weight gain, failure to regain birth weight, difficulty suckling, vomiting, dehydration and even cardiovascular collapse. [Dehydration in children SD-032 [Icterus in newborns SD-048]]

Neonatal screening for classic forms has been systematic in France since 1995 (measurement of 17-hydroxyprogesterone on blotting paper on the third day of life). [Systematic newborn screening SD-308

In older children and adolescents, the symptoms will be the same as those described for adults (see above).


Adrenoleukodystrophy combines adrenal insufficiency with neurological disorders that progressively worsen, but vary in intensity and date of onset. Adrenal insufficiency may initially appear isolated.

question.title: What is the primary clinical presentation of primary adrenal insufficiency in children?
question.description: The clinical diagnosis in little girls is an abnormality of the external genitalia (from clitoral hypertrophy to a male appearance without testicles). The boy's genitals are normal.

option_a.title: Hypertonia and convulsions
option_a.description: A common presentation of primary adrenal insufficiency in children

option_b.title: Abnormalities of the external genitalia (from clitoral hypertrophy to a male appearance without testicles)
option_b.description: The primary clinical presentation of primary adrenal insufficiency in children

option_c.title: Hypoglycaemia and cardiovascular collapse
option_c.description: A possible presentation of primary adrenal insufficiency in children

option_d.title: Neonatal jaundice and respiratory distress
option_d.description: A common presentation of primary adrenal insufficiency in newborns
